message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic deadband intermittent event-triggered strategy for formation control of multiple unmanned surface vehicles
Paper Abstract: This paper focuses on the leaderless formation control of multiple unmanned surface vehicles (MUSVs) with external disturbances, communication interruptions, and model parametric uncertainties. Firstly, the auxiliary variables are introduced to transform MUSVs’ formation control into consensus achievement of these auxiliary variables. Then, to realize consensus of these auxiliary variables, the reference variables which can achieve the average consensus are defined based on the proposed dynamic deadband intermittent event-triggered mechanism (ETM). Superior to general dynamic ETMs, the proposed dynamic deadband ETM applies nonlinear coupled communication protocols and ensures the existence of positive minimum inter-event times (PMIET). Further, by guaranteeing the auxiliary variables superior tracking capability for the reference variables, the consensus of the auxiliary variables can be achieved. Thus, the desired formation is realized. Besides, the adaptive strategy and the radial basis function neural network (RBFNN) are utilized against external disturbances and dynamic uncertainties. Finally, through rigorous theoretical analysis and numerical simulations, the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method are effectively demonstrated.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "multi-agent systems":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Characteristics

Key characteristics of agents in a multi-agent system include autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Composition and Types

The agents in a multi-agent system could be robots, humans, or human teams, and a multi-agent system may contain combined human-agent teams.(no content)The systems tend to prevent propagation of faults, self-recover and be fault tolerant, mainly due to the redundancy of components.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Research Areas

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

Web search results for query: "consensus algorithm distributed"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Raft (algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raft_(algorithm)"},{"title":"Distributed algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_algorithm"},{"title":"Paxos (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Distributed ledger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_ledger"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Chandra–Toueg consensus algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandra–Toueg_consensus_algorithm"},{"title":"Blockchain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockchain"},{"title":"Category:Distributed algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Distributed_algorithms"},{"title":"Distributed SQL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_SQL"}]

## Consensus Algorithm in Distributed Systems

Here's an overview of consensus algorithms in distributed computing:

### What is Consensus?

A fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of a number of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

### Common Consensus Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants of it such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems.

**Paxos**: Consensus protocols are the basis for the state machine replication approach to distributed computing, as suggested by Leslie Lamport. State machine replication is a technique for converting an algorithm into a fault-tolerant, distributed implementation.

**Raft**: Raft offers a generic way to distribute a state machine across a cluster of computing systems, ensuring that each node in the cluster agrees upon the same series of state transitions.(no content)Raft achieves consensus via an elected leader.

### Applications

Example applications of consensus include agreeing on what transactions to commit to a database in which order, state machine replication, and atomic broadcasts.(no content)Real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

I've performed a web search for "deadband control systems" and found relevant information. Here's what I found:

## Deadband in Control Systems

A deadband (also known as a dead zone or neutral zone) is a band of input values in a control system where the output is zero—no action occurs.

### Applications and Purpose

Deadbands serve several practical purposes in control systems:

1. **Reducing Mechanical Wear**: In PID loops controlling mechanical devices like valves, output deadbands can reduce the frequency of activation by holding the output steady if the change would be small.

2. **Compensating for Backlash**: Leadscrews have backlash and hence a deadband that must be accounted for when making position adjustments, especially in CNC systems, and control can compensate by adding the deadband value to the position vector when direction is reversed.

3. **Temperature Control**: A thermostat that automatically controls both heating and cooling exhibits a deadband range around the target temperature, with the low end just above where heating turns on and the high end just below where air-conditioning starts.

### Deadband vs. Hysteresis

It's important to note that deadband is different from hysteresis—deadband is the range where no changes to output are made, while hysteresis is the difference in a variable depending on the direction of travel.

I've completed the web search for "unmanned surface vehicle". Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned surface vehicle (USV), also called an unmanned surface vessel or uncrewed surface vessel, colloquially known as a drone boat, drone ship or sea drone, is a boat or ship that operates on the surface of the water without a crew.(no content)USVs operate with various levels of autonomy, from remote control to fully autonomous surface vehicles (ASV).

## Applications

USVs have diverse applications across multiple sectors:

**Commercial/Scientific:**
Non-renewable-powered USVs are a powerful tool for commercial hydrographic survey, and using a small USV in parallel to traditional survey vessels as a 'force-multiplier' can double survey coverage and reduce time on-site.(no content)A saildrone is a type of uncrewed surface vehicle used primarily in oceans for data collection and is wind and solar powered.

**Military:**
The Fleet class Unmanned Surface Vessel is a small, semi-planing hull craft intended to conduct anti-submarine warfare, special warfare, mine warfare and electronic warfare missions.(no content)The Protector unmanned surface vehicle was developed by the Israeli Rafael Advanced Defense Systems in response to emerging terrorist threats against maritime assets and is the first operational combat USV in service.

## Current Development and Deployment

Ukraine's 385th Naval Unmanned Surface Vehicles Brigade, established in August 2023, is the world's first specialized brigade dedicated to the operation of naval USVs.

Web search results for query: "event triggered control"

Links: [{"title":"Time-triggered architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-triggered_architecture"},{"title":"Time-Triggered Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-Triggered_Protocol"},{"title":"Event (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_handler"},{"title":"Maurice Heemels - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Heemels"},{"title":"DOM event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_Events"},{"title":"Event-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Event-driven programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_driven_programming"},{"title":"Event-driven process chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_process_chain"},{"title":"Trauma trigger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigger_warnings"},{"title":"Inversion of control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_of_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about event-triggered control:

## Event-Triggered Control

Event-triggered systems refer to a field of study involving contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems, which is a specialized area in control theory and engineering.

Event-triggered control is distinct from time-based control approaches. Time-triggered architecture (TTA) is a computer system that executes one or more sets of tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, whereas event-triggered systems respond to events as they occur rather than following a fixed schedule.

## Related Concepts

**Event-Driven Architecture**: Event-driven architecture (EDA) is a software architecture paradigm concerning the production and detection of events. An event can be defined as "a significant change in state". For example, when a consumer purchases a car, the car's state changes from "for sale" to "sold". A car dealer's system architecture may treat this state change as an event whose occurrence can be made known to other applications within the architecture.

**Event-Driven Programming**: In an event-driven application, there is generally an event loop that listens for events and then triggers a callback function when one of those events is detected.

Event-triggered control is commonly used in applications where actions need to be taken in response to specific occurrences rather than on a fixed time schedule, such as in automation systems, software frameworks, and distributed computing environments.

Web search results for query: "radial basis function neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Radial basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Radial basis function kernel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_kernel"},{"title":"Types of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_feedback"},{"title":"Hyper basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Random feature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_feature"},{"title":"Activation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Activation_function"},{"title":"Feedforward neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptrons"},{"title":"Radial basis function interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_interpolation"},{"title":"Kansa method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansa_method"}]

I've found comprehensive information about radial basis function neural networks. Here's an overview:

## Definition and Structure

A radial basis function network is an artificial neural network that uses radial basis functions as activation functions.(no content)RBF networks typically have three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with a non-linear RBF activation function and a linear output layer.

## How They Work

The output of the network is a linear combination of radial basis functions of the inputs and neuron parameters.(no content)The norm is typically taken to be the Euclidean distance and the radial basis function is commonly taken to be Gaussian.(no content)Changing parameters of one neuron has only a small effect for input values that are far away from the center of that neuron.

## Applications and History

Radial basis function networks have many uses, including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control.(no content)They were first formulated in a 1988 paper by Broomhead and Lowe, both researchers at the Royal Signals and Radar Establishment.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

RBF networks have the advantage of avoiding local minima in the same way as multi-layer perceptrons because the only parameters that are adjusted in the learning process are the linear mapping from hidden layer to output layer. Linearity ensures that the error surface is quadratic and therefore has a single easily found minimum.

However, RBF networks have the disadvantage of requiring good coverage of the input space by radial basis functions. RBF centres are determined with reference to the distribution of the input data, but without reference to the prediction task. As a result, representational resources may be wasted on areas of the input space that are irrelevant to the task.

Links: [{"title":"Radial basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Radial basis function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function"},{"title":"Radial basis function kernel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_kernel"},{"title":"Types of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_feedback"},{"title":"Hyper basis function network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyper_basis_function_network"},{"title":"Random feature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_feature"},{"title":"Activation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Activation_function"},{"title":"Feedforward neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptrons"},{"title":"Radial basis function interpolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radial_basis_function_interpolation"},{"title":"Kansa method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansa_method"}]

I've found comprehensive information about radial basis function neural networks. Here's an overview:

## Definition and Structure

A radial basis function network is an artificial neural network that uses radial basis functions as activation functions.(no content)RBF networks typically have three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with a non-linear RBF activation function and a linear output layer.

## How They Work

The output of the network is a linear combination of radial basis functions of the inputs and neuron parameters.(no content)The norm is typically taken to be the Euclidean distance and the radial basis function is commonly taken to be Gaussian.(no content)Changing parameters of one neuron has only a small effect for input values that are far away from the center of that neuron.

## Applications and History

Radial basis function networks have many uses, including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control.(no content)They were first formulated in a 1988 paper by Broomhead and Lowe, both researchers at the Royal Signals and Radar Establishment.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

RBF networks have the advantage of avoiding local minima in the same way as multi-layer perceptrons because the only parameters that are adjusted in the learning process are the linear mapping from hidden layer to output layer. Linearity ensures that the error surface is quadratic and therefore has a single easily found minimum.

However, RBF networks have the disadvantage of requiring good coverage of the input space by radial basis functions. RBF centres are determined with reference to the distribution of the input data, but without reference to the prediction task. As a result, representational resources may be wasted on areas of the input space that are irrelevant to the task.

I've completed the web search for "adaptive control systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain. For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Distinctions

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Technical Foundations

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Historical Context

Adaptive controls were applied for the first time in the aerospace industry in the 1950s, and have found particular success in that field.

## Real-World Applications

Adaptive control systems are used in various domains, including:
- **Flight control**: A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.
- **Traffic management**: Adaptive traffic control system (ATCS) is a traffic management strategy in which traffic signal timing changes, or adapts, based on actual traffic demand.
- **Automotive**: Adaptive cruise control (ACC) is a type of advanced driver-assistance system for road vehicles that automatically adjusts the vehicle speed to maintain a safe distance from vehicles ahead.

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_neural_network"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"},{"title":"File:Artificial Neural Network.gif","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Artificial_Neural_Network.gif"}]

I've performed a web search for "neural network" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here's an overview of the key findings:

## What is a Neural Network?

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain. In the context of machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Structure and Architecture

Neurons in an artificial neural network are usually arranged into layers, with information passing from the first layer (the input layer) through one or more intermediate layers (the hidden layers) to the final layer (the output layer).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.

## Applications

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence. More specifically, neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.

## Historical Context

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.(no content)In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of control theory:

## Definition and Purpose

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems, with the aim to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable and compares it with the reference or set point, and the difference between actual and desired value—called the error signal—is applied as feedback to generate a control action.

## Historical Development

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)The field was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to control stability criteria, and from 1922 onwards, Nicolas Minorsky developed PID control theory.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Beyond direct application in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems in both natural and behavioral sciences, and is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence).

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence).

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - This paper proposes novel methods and techniques for formation control of MUSVs.

**Extracted Entities:** 8 triples covering key technologies and methodologies:

1. **Unmanned surface vehicle** (artifact) - The primary system being controlled
2. **Deadband** (concept) - Core novel contribution: dynamic deadband intermittent event-triggered mechanism
3. **Control theory** (concept) - Foundational framework used throughout
4. **Consensus (computer science)** (method) - Algorithm basis for formation control strategy
5. **Radial basis function network** (method) - Used for handling uncertainties and disturbances
6. **Adaptive control** (method) - Strategy for addressing parametric uncertainties
7. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - System architecture for coordinated vehicle control
8. **Neural network (machine learning)** (method) - Foundation for the RBFNN approach

**Validation Result:** ✅ **PASSED** - All 8 triples validated successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs and formatting.

The triples_output.json file has been updated with all entities properly classified and linked to their Wikipedia resources.
